Stories like Martha‚Äôs echo across our region and nation, yet fearing judgment from classmates and family members, young people too often suffer in silence and solitude. If you or someone you know needs help, call @800273TALK.

Thanks to the County‚Äôs steadfast support, we have expanded the youth suicide prevention program to 35 schools throughout the San Gabriel Valley and southeast LA County. The program serves as a model for my legislation, the Mental Health Services for Students Act (H.R. 1109).
18 years ago, I secured federal funding to place local mental health provider, Pacific Clinics, in one high school and three middle schools in LA County; one of these schools was Martha‚Äôs.

Martha went through a stage of darkness when she came to terms w/ her sexuality at age 15 and felt confused, fearful, guilty, sad & lonely, as many LGBTQ youth do. A close friend reached out to her, understood her, supported her, and encouraged her to seek mental health services.

I invite you to read my Op-Ed on the importance of funding mental health services in schools for youth like Martha, an 18 y/o Latina college student from La Puente. https://www.sgvtribune.com/2019/07/06/lifelines-help-prevent-teen-suicides/¬†‚Ä¶
